item.title: Beware Becoming The Hero
item.description: Ah, the hero. The gallant, the brave, the ever-present and ever-helpful champion of many a software venture. But beware of what lies just beneath the surface.

item.title: The dangers of overplaying the edge case card
item.description: Making lots of small decisions that are suboptimal but only affect a small amount of your user base is deceptively damaging over time.

item.title: In Aviation
item.description: An important lesson that has been learned in safety critical environments such as aviation over decades of flying and - sadly - numerous accidents, is that one layer of safety is not enough. In aviation, important actions are always checked and confirmed multiple times, often by different people using different methods or with different areas of expertise.

item.title: Make Everyone a Tester
item.description: One of the most damaging elements of traditional software development culture has been a strict allocation of duties between disciplines.

item.title: Boring Testers
item.description: Testing really doesn’t have to be boring. There is a certain subset of testers that just make me want to quit testing though.

item.title: Test Automation Is Not Magic
item.description: Over the years as I’ve been a part of numerous web development projects which lack test automation. A recurring theme is the idea that test automation is magic. It isn’t.
